utterances: A recent poll by Tel Aviv University found that half of Israelis believe nothing will come out of Annapolis.
At the same time, a large majority of the Jewish population believes in a two-state solution, meaning an independent Palestinian state alongside Israel.
At a Jerusalem pharmacy, Ruti Kleimen(ph), a Hebrew teacher, says she's worried about Annapolis meeting.
Because I'm afraid that as a result for me, territories will give back.
For me, it's not territories.
For me, it's about my land.
I'm referring to Israel.
To my opinion, it belongs to the Jewish people.
Kleimen says Israelis should look at the president of Gaza.
In 2005, Israel dismantled the Jewish settlements in Gaza and pulled all of its troops out.
Since then, Hamas has taken over and towns in southern Israel live with daily Palestinian rocket attacks.
But other Israelis believe there is a chance that the Annapolis meeting could lead to a peace deal.
Havivi Israeli(ph) is the owner of a Jerusalem clothing store nearby.
I hope so.
I'm not believing it.
I hope so...
Why?
...with all my heart.
After all this year, I don't know if it will be okay.
I hope so.
Israeli says both Israelis and Palestinians need to be willing to compromise.
And, he says, what's important about the Annapolis conference is that all of the most divisive issues will be on the table.
Sit, talk about everything, everything from A to Z.
Not to leave anything to a later.
And then, make peace.
Linda Gradstein, NPR News, Jerusalem.
In Chicago this weekend, something is happening that hasn't happened since 1918: The Chicago Cubs are playing the Boston Red Sox.
In fact, the last time the Red Sox played in the Windy City, a fellow named Babe Ruth was on their roster.
It was the 1918 World Series, and the teams played at Comiskey Park.
Today was the Red Sox's first time ever in Wrigley Field, and the Cubs won the first game of this interleague series 14-6.
During the game, I spoke with Cubs fan George Lucas.
No relation to the movie maker.
He was at Wrigley Field.
He's owner of the bar the Cubby Bear, which is across the street from the ballpark.
He said Cubs fans take inspiration from the Red Sox.
Until the Sox won the World Series last year, both teams had a long history of losing.
Yes, it certainly is.
And hopefully, the Boston curse that rubbed off will help us--they'll help us rub off this year with our curse.
I wonder what that's like to have these two teams meeting together in Wrigley Field for the first time.
Do you get a sense that this is a historic moment?
Unidentified Man #2 (Actor): (As character) You know, Fern, look.
You know I've been selling the animals to get the new harvesting equipment.
Pretty soon there's going to be no place in the barn for a pig.
(As Fern) I promised I'd take care of him.
Unidentified Man #2: (As character) Well, I'm letting you out of your promise.
(As Fern) I didn't promise you.
I promised Wilbur.
But before you think Hollywood has got lit-git, think again.
A look at what's upcoming next year shows the industry still likes to make movies based on movies, not books.
The big titles studios are touting for 2007 include ""Spiderman 3,"" ""Fantastic Four 2,"" ""Ocean's Thirteen,"" ""Shrek 3,"" ""Pirates of the Caribbean 3,"" ""Alien v.

Predator 2,"" ""National Treasure 2"" and ""Saw 4."" If the prospect of these films doesn't whet your cinematic appetite, look on the bright side: You'll just have more time to catch up on your reading.
Pete Hammond is a film critic for Maxim magazine.
Good morning.
I'm Steve Inskeep.
The U.S.
election campaign has already featured online hacking.
Sri Lanka has political hacking, too.
And unlike the United States, it caught the culprit.
Sri Lanka's Daily News reports police arrested a 17-year-old.
The student allegedly took down the website of the country's president.
The home page was replaced by a demand that the president postpone advanced-level school examinations or else resign.
You're listening to MORNING EDITION.
This is TALK OF THE NATION/SCIENCE FRIDAY.
I'm Ira Flatow.

Each year as a holiday treat, we bring you our broadcast of highlights from the Ig Nobel Awards Ceremony, an event at which the publishers of the magazine the Annals of Improbable Research salute the strange and silly in science.
And they find plenty of it.
As they say, they pay tribute to work that first makes people laugh and then makes them think.

This year marks the 15th First Annual Ig Nobel Awards Ceremony, and it's a place--if you've never been to it, you have to watch out, because there are paper airplanes flying through the air more or less at will.
Most of them are aimed at the people onstage, where long-winded speeches are cut short by a little girl complaining that she's bored.
So sit close to the radio, stare straight into the speakers, and imagine yourself in Harvard's Sanders Theater.
Unidentified Woman #1: Ladies and gentlemen, boys and girls, literati, glitterati, pseudo-intellectuals, quasi-pseudo-intellectuals and presidential science advisers...
(Soundbite of cheers, applause)
...may I introduce our master of ceremonies, the editor of the Annals of Improbable Research, chief airhead Marc Abrahams.
(Soundbite of applause)
Thank you.
We are gathered here tonight to honor some remarkable individuals and groups.
Every winner has done something that first makes people laugh and then makes them think.
Tonight 10 prizes will be given.
The achievements speak for themselves all too eloquently.
Now Dr. Micheline Matthews-Roth will give the traditional Ig Nobel `Welcome, welcome' speech.
Welcome.
Welcome.
(Soundbite of cheers, applause)
The editors of the Annals of Improbable Research have chosen a theme for this year's ceremony.
This year's theme is infinity.
(Soundbite of cheers, applause)
To fully explain and illustrate this year's theme, which I remind you is infinity...
(Soundbite of cheers, applause)
...we have commissioned a series of educational lectures.
These are called the Infinite Lectures.
There are three of them.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Each lecturer will strictly adhere to the time limit, which is infinity.
(Soundbite of laughter)
The first infinite lecturer is Nobel laureate Dudley Herschbach, who will explain the concept of infinity.
(Soundbite of cheers, applause)
It's a very simple concept, but you have to understand a lot of other concepts.
You have to understand the concept of one, of two, of three, of four, of five, and minus one, minus two...
The second infinite lecturer is Nobel laureate Robert Wilson, who will recite, in their proper order, all of the digits of the number pi.
The third and final infinite lecturer is Nobel laureate Sheldon Glashow, who will tell you everything he knows.
Well, it's hard to top Bob Wilson.
I can give you the digits of E, but let me start in the year that I was born, which is 1932, when the...
(Soundbite of cheers, applause)
There is a musical feast: the world premiere of a new mini-opera called ""The Count of Infinity."" There are three acts, three acts: one now, two--yes, that's two--later.
The opera stars Margot Button, Simon Chausse, pianist Greg Neil and many of the scientists who are with us onstage tonight.
Now here is our narrator, Karen Hopkin.
The Countess of Infinity rules over the land of Infinity--which, let me tell you, is a pretty big place.
The countess wants to fall in love, get married and have children, but first--first--she has to complete a count of everything she owns.
She is going to count everything in the land of infinity.
That's because the countess suffers from a psychological disorder.
It's called OCD, obsessive-compulsive disorder.
The countess needs help, so she hires a handsome young accountant to assist in the counting.
Let's join them at their first meeting.
(Soundbite of song, to the tune of Mozart's ""Eine Kleine Nachtmusik"")
It's indescribable in clear weather to start your descent, and it's almost a two-dimensional view.
And then once you get down into the mountains like Helena or Bozeman and see the majestic peaks around you, it's just absolutely an amazing sight.
